thread.title: Human rights groups warn against social media use in the United Arab Emirates

author: Katie Amey for MailOnline
title: Human rights groups warn against social media use in the United Arab Emirates
text:
47 shares 11
View
comments
It's a luxurious oasis in the middle of the desert, but campaign groups have argued that the United Arab Emirates has a repressive side.
Several expats working in the UAE have been arrested for their posts on social networking sites, under the nation's repressive laws governing online commentary.
Recent events have prompted human rights groups to warn visitors against speaking out on social media.
Several expats, all of whom live and work in the UAE, have been arrested for their posts on social media sites
The warnings were principally sparked by Australian Jodi Magi, who was reportedly arrested in Abu Dhabi last month for posting an image on Facebook of a vehicle blocking two disabled car spots outside of her apartment block.
The artist was apparently jailed for writing 'bad words about a person' on social media, according the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and did not understand what she had done wrong.

Un-icyclists rejoice: North Korea installs bike paths... 47 shares Laws targeting so-called 'Cyber Crimes' were first enacted in 2012 and make it an offence to use the internet to criticise the state, its rulers, and even other citizens.
Unfortunately, however, these laws have punished everyone from political dissidents to innocent citizens making innocuous comments.
In the UAE, it is against the law to post anything negative about the state or other citizens on the internet
Australian artist Jodi Magi was arrested in Abu Dhabi for writing 'bad words about a person' on social media
In February, an American engineer working in the UAE was arrested over a Facebook post about his employers that he wrote while on holiday back home.
He had referred to his company, Global Aerospace Logistics, as 'backstabbers' and also made negative remarks about Arab people.
Upon his return to Abu Dhabi, he was arrested on charges of 'cyberslander,' according to CNN and reported by SMH.com.au.
Eventually, after receiving widespread media coverage, the case was dropped and the man returned to the United States.
Interestingly, human rights groups, such as Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, are currently not permitted to operate in the UAE.
Human rights groups, who are not permitted to operate in the UAE, have criticised this practice as a 'draconian attitude to freedom of expression'
Nicholas McGeehan, a UAE researcher with Human Rights Watch, said that the Gulf nation was a more repressive place than many people realised, according to SMH.com.au .
'The image that people have of Dubai and Abu Dhabi is at odds with the reality, I think of the situation there,' he said.
'You now have a cybercrime spree, which acts in conjunction with strong defamation laws where basically anyone who says anything online, makes any comment online about another person, could fall foul of those laws, if someone complains about them, particularly if someone has any connection to the authorities.'
'There is a draconian attitude to freedom of expression, and a notable lack of common sense or even sense of humour,' he added.
Some human rights organisations believe that governments in Britain and Australia, among others, need to better make their own citizens aware of the UAE's restrictive laws regarding freedom of expression.
According to the Foreign Office, travellers are warned against 'swearing or making rude gestures (including online)' as they 'are considered obscene acts and offenders could be jailed or deported.'
The FCO also advises British travellers to 'take particular care when dealing with the police and other officials'.
